**Grayswandir** is an [artifact weapon](/wiki/Artifact_weapon "Artifact weapon") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is [lawful](/wiki/Lawful "Lawful")-aligned, and its [base item](/wiki/Base_item "Base item") is a [silver saber](/wiki/Silver_saber "Silver saber").

[ ]

## Generation

A randomly generated silver saber has a 1⁄20 chance of being generated as an artifact, which has a 1⁄2 chance of being Grayswandir (and will otherwise be [Werebane](/wiki/Werebane "Werebane"), the other artifact silver saber) if no artifacts have already been generated. Lawful characters may receive Grayswandir as a sacrifice gift.

[Player monsters](/wiki/Player_monster "Player monster") on the [Astral Plane](/wiki/Astral_Plane "Astral Plane") that generate with a silver saber have a 1⁄2 chance of that saber being turned into a compatible artifact that is not yet generated, resulting in an effective 1⁄4 chance of the saber becoming Grayswandir if no artifact saber are generated.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

## Description

Grayswandir deals [double damage](/wiki/Double_damage "Double damage") to all targets, with the doubling applied to the weapon's base dice and any enchantment followed by silver damage and other bonuses, and confers [hallucination resistance](/wiki/Hallucination_resistance "Hallucination resistance") while wielded.

## Strategy

Grayswandir is one of the most sought-after artifact weapons in *NetHack*, both for general use and [twoweapon](/wiki/Twoweapon "Twoweapon"): while it lacks utilities outside of resistance to a status [property](/wiki/Property "Property") that characters can avoid by selectively [blinding](/wiki/Blind "Blind") themselves and cure with a [unicorn horn](/wiki/Unicorn_horn "Unicorn horn"), it more than makes up for this with sheer damage output, especially at high skill in saber and against silver-hating monsters like [vampires](/wiki/Vampire_\(monster_class\) "Vampire (monster class)") and [major demons](/wiki/Major_demon "Major demon"). It is also not [intelligent](/wiki/Intelligent "Intelligent") and so can be used by non-lawfuls, with the only risk being a 1⁄4 chance of 4d4 damage each time they touch the artifact.

Due to damage calculation, Grayswandir shines most when it is heavily-enchanted, and is arguably most useful in the late game, when characters are guaranteed to encounter several silver haters and will have enchanted the weapon a reasonable amount - ironically, this is also where artifact weapon selection *matters* less: hit points, magic defenses, evasion strategies, and armor class are each just as valuable as weapon damage at this stage, if not more so. Characters in the early game should prioritize survival and a consistent source of damage before trying to maximize said damage, while late-game characters with more available artifact weapons that can do more damage at Basic skill before enchantments (such as [Excalibur](/wiki/Excalibur "Excalibur")) should stay the course, unless they really want the extra damage.

### Average damage calculation

The average damage calculations in the following table do not include bonuses from [weapon skills](/wiki/Skill "Skill"), [strength](/wiki/Strength "Strength"), or from using a [blessed](/wiki/Blessed "Blessed") weapon against [undead](/wiki/Undead "Undead") or demons. In addition, remember that double damage applies to the damage from base dice and enchantment.

| Weapon         | Not silver-hating                                                                                            | Silver-hating                                                                                                                 |
| -------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ | ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| +0 Grayswandir | ![\left (\frac{1+8}{2}\right )\times 2=\bold{9}](/images/math/6/d/8/6d838c3450b4061f3a10761d00a22607.png)    | ![\left (\frac{1+8}{2}\right )\times 2+\frac{1+20}{2}=\bold{19.5}](/images/math/2/7/d/27d92d3208d31ac94f0abfed4ffed20e.png)   |
| +7 Grayswandir | ![\left (\frac{1+8}{2}+7\right )\times 2=\bold{23}](/images/math/4/5/6/45682c50da95cf21803c259b74f575a8.png) | ![\left (\frac{1+8}{2}+7\right )\times 2+\frac{1+20}{2}=\bold{33.5}](/images/math/a/b/c/abc06d072c68b2bc08832c47e026391d.png) |

## History

Grayswandir first appears in [NetHack 3.1.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.1.0 "NetHack 3.1.0").

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Grayswandir](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:Search/Grayswandir "wikipedia:Special:Search/Grayswandir")***

Grayswandir, is a weapon from *[Chronicles of Amber](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chronicles_of_Amber "wikipedia:Chronicles of Amber")* book series by [Roger Zelanzy](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roger_Zelanzy "wikipedia:Roger Zelanzy"). Also known as the Night Blade, Grayswandir is the silver sword of theprotagonist, Corwin, and has a twin called Brand's Werewindle, the Day Sword. Both swords are inscribed with portions of the Pattern of Amber, granting them some power over Shadow, and Corwin is able to call Grayswandir to him while travelling in the region. The sword also enables him to speak to the shades of Tir-na Nog'th and inflict damage on the hostile ones he fights.

The weapon's name and its abilities echo that of Graywand, the longsword of Fafhrd in the [Fritz Leiber](/wiki/Fritz_Leiber "Fritz Leiber") tales of *[Fafhrd and the Gray Mouser](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fafhrd_and_the_Gray_Mouser "wikipedia:Fafhrd and the Gray Mouser")*: Fafhrd naming consecutive swords Graywand after losing the previous one may be the basis for Grayswandir reappearing to Corwin even after being lost.

## Variants

### NetHack: The Next Generation

In [NetHack: The Next Generation](/wiki/NetHack:_The_Next_Generation "NetHack: The Next Generation"), Grayswandir is the most expensive artifact available at [The Forge](/wiki/The_Forge "The Forge") with a base price of 17,500 [zm](/wiki/Zm "Zm").

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), Grayswandir's to-hit bonus is a flat +5 and it can be used in the offhand when twoweaponing - the artifact functions the same otherwise.

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), Grayswandir confers [warning](/wiki/Warning "Warning") while carried, always hits insubstantial monsters, and deals an additional +9 damage against non-lawful monsters.

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), Grayswandir can be combined with [Dragonbane](/wiki/Dragonbane "Dragonbane") at a [forge](/wiki/Forge_\(dungeon_feature\) "Forge (dungeon feature)") to create the [Gauntlets of Purity](/wiki/Gauntlets_of_Purity "Gauntlets of Purity").

### SlashTHEM

In addition to SLASH'EM details, [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM") incorporates The Forge from NetHack: The Next Generation, and Grayswandir is available there with the same base price - it is the second-most expensive artifact available there after [Houchou](/wiki/Houchou "Houchou").

## Encyclopedia entry

Why had I been wearing Grayswandir? Would another weapon have affected a Logrus-ghost as strongly? Had it really been my father, then, who had brought me here? And had he felt I might need the extra edge his weapon could provide? I wanted to think so, to believe that he had been more than a Pattern-ghost.

\[ Knight of Shadows, by Roger Zelazny ]
